text:
There have been at least two prior updates for WinRE (to resolve a different
Bitlocker issue and a Secure Boot issue) but it required some manual work to
update it on Windows 10 (Microsoft only had an updater for Windows 11).
Installing this update would resolve all the past issues as well. I've been
running some tests on Windows 10 22H2, and I found (at least so far) that if the
update is installed manually it may succeed where the automatic update install
failed (your results may be different). If it failed to install, you should find
the update in your C:\Windows\SoftwareDistribution\Download folder (in a random
subfolder, file name WinREUpdateInstaller_2401B_amd64.exe). If it downloaded but
hasn't tried to install, you would find it in the Download folder with a
hexadecimal name and no extension; the file size is 23,850,992 bytes; you can
copy and rename the file to an EXE (it is a self-extracting archive file).
Right-click and "run as administrator", it runs silently and takes a few
minutes. You can monitor the activity on the Task Manager details tab. You can
use this PowerShell command before and after to verify the WinRE build installed
(post-update will show build 3920): (Get-WindowsImage -ImagePath ((reagentc
/info | findstr "\\?\GLOBALROOT\device").Replace("Windows RE location: ",
"").Trim() + "\winre.wim") -Index 1).SPBuild Jody MacKercher Positron Computer
Services

metadata.subject: RE: [patchmanagement] You may hit a 0x80070643 - ERROR_INSTALL_FAILURE
metadata.email_text_original:

Services -----Original Message----- From: 'Susan Bradley' via PatchManagement
Sent: Wednesday, January 10, 2024 12:04 PM To: patchmanagement@googlegroups.com
Subject: Re: [patchmanagement] You may hit a 0x80070643 - ERROR_INSTALL_FAILURE
What annoys me the most is that my home Windows 10 machine that has no TPM and
thus no way to get bitlocker enabled it getting this update. Microsoft come on-
make detection for this smarter. I'm not going to wipe and reload, I'm going to
complain and grumble until someone pulls this sucker and makes detection for
this issue better.
Link: None
metadata.evaluated_keywords: ['task manager detail tab', 'automatic update install fail', 'secure boot issue', 'windows 10 22h2']
metadata.evaluated_noun_chunks: ["at least two prior updates", "this update", "the automatic update install", "your C:\\Windows\\SoftwareDistribution\\Download folder"]
metadata.noun_chunks: ["at least two prior updates", "this update", "the automatic update install", "your C:\\Windows\\SoftwareDistribution\\Download folder"]
